TikTok's new owners include many whose business or political interests are tied to Mr Trump, including Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison and Rupert Murdoch, raising questions about whether political influence will be exerted on the platform.

Lachlan Murdoch involved in possible TikTok deal, Trump says Photo shows A young man and an older man sit together in sporting stands The deal would see TikTok's American assets transferred from China's ByteDance to American owners.

Although he stepped down as Oracle's chief executive more than a decade ago, Mr Ellison remains heavily involved in its operations, as chairman and chief technology officer.

Now 81, he could be in line to become a behind-the-scenes media power player, having already helped finance Skydance's recently completed $8 billion merger with Paramount, a deal engineered by his son, David.

Mr Trump also mentioned tech giant Dell founder Michael Dell will be an investor in the new venture.

What about the algorithm?

The recommendation algorithm that has steered millions of users into an endless stream of video shorts has been central in the security debate over TikTok.

China previously maintained the algorithm must remain under Chinese control by law.

But a US regulation that Congress passed with bipartisan support said any divestment of TikTok must mean the platform cuts ties with ByteDance.

American officials previously warned that the algorithm — which is a complex system of rules and calculations that platforms use to deliver content to your feed — is vulnerable to manipulation by Chinese authorities, who can use it to shape messaging on the platform in a way that's difficult to detect, but no evidence has ever been presented by US officials showing that China has attempted to do so.

During his first term, Mr Trump signed an executive order attempting to ban the app if it didn't split off its US business, warning at the time that TikTok's "data collection threatens to allow the Chinese Communist Party access to Americans' personal and proprietary information".

Almost half (43 per cent) of US adults under 30 say they use TikTok as a source of news. (ABC News: Phoebe Pin)

Mr Trump has since changed his approach to TikTok, often citing its role in helping him reach young voters in the 2024 presidential election.

Although the details remain unclear, a Trump administration official said that a licensed copy of the ByteDance-created algorithm — retrained solely with US data — will power the new US version of the app, which they say will nullify any risk of Chinese interference and influence.

Young people especially "really wanted this to happen", Mr Trump said during the signing ceremony.

That makes it unclear if the US version of TikTok will be a different experience than what users in the rest of the world are used to.

Jasmine Enberg, an analyst for the research firm eMarketer, said that making noticeable changes to a social media platform's service risked alienating its audience.

In a prime example of how a change of control can reshape a once-popular social media platform, billionaire Elon Musk triggered an almost immediate backlash after he completed his takeover of Twitter nearly three years ago.

Mr Musk made extremely visible changes to the platform, including changing its name to X, pulling back on its content moderation and adding exclusive features for paid subscribers.

The changes that gradually occur while different data is fed into the US copy of TikTok's algorithm could be subtle and unnoticeable to most of its audience.

"Social media is just as much about the culture as it is the technology, and how users will take to new ownership and potentially a new version of the app is still an open question," Ms Enberg said.

What motivated China to make this deal?

Beijing once called the demand that TikTok be spun off from its Chinese parent company an act of "robbery", but Chinese officials changed their tune as the trade war with the US progressed.

Following the announcement of a possible TikTok framework deal after US–China trade talks in Spain, some observers believed that China was able to extract concessions from the US on loosening trade restrictions in exchange for the TikTok deal.

Others believe China was willing to do so to pave the way for a meeting between Mr Xi and Mr Trump.

A TikTok deal would allow China to keep the ball rolling on trade negotiations, said Sun Yun, director of the China program at the Washington-based think tank Stimson Center.

"TikTok alone does not compare with the importance of amicable US–China relations and the positive momentum that prevents many negative developments from happening."

What we know about how the under-16s social media ban will work Photo shows A graphic showing a hand holding a phone. It is superimposed on a drawing of Australia and surrounded by social media apps Australia is months away from implementing its world-first social media ban for teens. But questions still remain around how the restrictions will work.

Dimitar Gueorguiev, associate professor of political science at Syracuse University, said TikTok had become an "expendable concession" to Beijing because it was no longer a disruptive newcomer as it was five years ago.

TikTok's highly personalised "For You" video feed was seen as its secret sauce five years ago, when Mr Trump first threatened to ban the app, but Instagram and other rivals now work similarly.

Dr Gueorguiev argued that Beijing was more interested in retaining access to US technology and services, at least in the short term, so it could build up self-sufficiency in semiconductor, artificial intelligence and advanced manufacturing.

"That is the front line of technological competition," he said.

"TikTok, by contrast, is a maturing consumer app with diminishing strategic weight."

AP

title: Hiker with MND savours the 'stillness' one of Australia's most arduous treks
text:
Walking 1,000 kilometres with an 18-kilogram backpack is an ask for many, but add motor neurone disease and you have a challenge most would not attempt.

Mullumbimby woman Catherine Perversi has many reasons for taking on the Bibbulmun Track in Western Australia.

"I firmly believe long-term hiking imparts knowledge when you listen well and allow your ears and eyes to stay open to its [nature's] sounds and beauty," she said.

Three years ago, Ms Perversi began to experience difficulties with her speech, as words became hard to articulate.

She was diagnosed with MND in November last year.

It is a terminal, degenerative neurological disease that attacks and destroys the motor neurons responsible for voluntary muscle control, leading to progressive muscle weakness and eventual paralysis.

There is no known cure, although treatments can help manage symptoms.

Writing on her blog, Ms Perversi said the illness had made her world smaller.

Hiking with motor neurone disease means every step must be carefully planned. (Supplied: Pia Perversi-Burchall)

"I ache for more space — space that allows distance from the crowd of my repetitive thoughts," she said.

"My life has revolved around appointments with medical specialists, submitting my body to medical tests.

"I've become a science experiment.

"I'm preoccupied with clinical trials that aim to find a cure for MND, assistive devices for things like foot drop/drag, and manage symptoms such as excess mucous."

Raising awareness of MND is another reason for Ms Perversi to challenge herself, and she is also using the hike to raise funds for the MND and Me Foundation.

The charity cares for people living with MND and supports research into MND, and Ms Perversi hopes to raise $10,000 via GoFundMe.

Everyday challenges

Every step Ms Perversi takes carries risk, and even eating food is a risky task when you have MND.

"I try to be cognisant of the dangers inherent in talking with my mouth full, choking," she said.

Daughter Pia Perversi-Burchall said losing the capacity to communicate verbally had been a big hit for her mother.

Australia's first MND surveillance centre opens Photo shows A black and white photo of a woman and an older man wearing a hat and glasses. Researchers have established Australia's first motor neurone disease surveillance centre in a region where residents are three times more likely to contract the disease.

"Her voice has changed a lot — it is quite laboured and slurred," she said.

"Luckily, we can still have a conversation, but it is hard work for her."

However, Ms Perversi is at no loss for words when sharing her thoughts and experiences in her blog.

"I am living with a terminal disease that currently has no cure and no effective treatment," she said in a recent post.

"My life expectancy could be five years, of which I've already lived three since the onset of symptoms.

" Death is certain, its time is not. "

Catherine Perversi and Pia Perversi-Burchall have recently completed the Sunshine Coast Great Walk. (Supplied: Pia Perversi-Burchall)

Ms Perversi and her daughter recently completed the 60km Sunshine Coast Great Walk as preparation for the Bibbulmun Track.

But it did not start well.

Watch the new season of The Assembly on ABC iview Photo shows A young person holding a microphone standing amongst audience. Leigh Sales returns to mentor a new cohort of autistic journalism students from across the country as they interview some of Australia's favourite celebrities.

"[Mum] actually fell over three times in the first day and I thought, 'Oh my god, this is not going to happen,'" Ms Perversi-Burchall said.

"But she found her feet and energy and was incredible.

"On the last day, there was a really long incline up a really steep cliff face and she took her time.

"She would probably cringe at these words, but she is an inspiring woman."

Carrying 'the whole shebang'

Before her illness, Ms Perversi was a frequent hiker, completing the Camino de Santiago trail from southern France to Spain.

But she said the Bibbulmun Track — stretching from Kalamunda in the Perth Hills to Albany on the south coast — was no Camino.

"The 800km Camino is as challenging as any long hike — the difficult sections are real (and very eagerly forgotten) and most people are beset by injury and egg-sized blisters at some point," Ms Perversi said.

Catherine Perversi and her friend Rebecca Ryall check a pack before the hike. (Supplied: Pia Perversi-Burchall)

"[However] everything on the Camino is on tap: warm beds, hot meals, fellow pilgrims to massage your shoulders, café con leche every few kilometres, and even a free wine fountain en route.

"The Bibbulmun Track, on the other hand, requires you to carry the whole shebang."

Two friends are walking the track for support and will meet up with Ms Perversi each night, and volunteer group Track Angels will drop food at regular intervals along the way.

Catherine Perversi says she enjoys the "silence" of a long walk. (Supplied: Catherine Perversi)

The Bibbulmun has always been on Ms Perversi's to-do list, but her MND has made the trek feel more urgent.

"Given there's no way of knowing if I'll still have the use of my legs and arms in a year's time due to MND, there's no better time than now," she said.

The lure of nature also drives Ms Perversi forward.

"The track passes through a universally recognised biodiversity nerve centre, where 80 per cent of the plant species are found nowhere else on earth," she said.

" During September, October, it's wildflower season. "

The wildflowers along the Bibbulmun Track are a constant source of delight for hikers. (Supplied: Catherine Perversi)

The first week of trekking has offered Ms Perversi hard times and pearls of joy.

"I'm finding my trail feet still, today I was tired and had a couple of slips, abrasions only," she said.

"I walked only 40 kilometres in four days, a paltry amount in comparison to most."

But the benefits of walking are evident.

"I'm happy, I wouldn't be anywhere else," Ms Perversi said.

"The stillness is sublime."

title: This deaf woman was 12 before learning Auslan, now she's teaching others
text:
Access to language is essential for the Deaf community, but it isn't always guaranteed — especially in isolated parts of Australia.

Nichole Davis spent the first decade of her life lip-reading because her family didn't know how to sign and was 12 years old when she finally met another deaf person.

Communicating through interpreter Bettina Girdler, Ms Davis said she "was blown away" the first time she saw someone using sign language.

Nichole Davis teaches Auslan in Darwin. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Now, she works in Darwin for Deaf Connect — the nation's largest deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing service provider — where she has been teaching Auslan, the language of deaf Australians, for two years.

Thriving Deaf spaces

Events across Australia, including a social game of lawn bowls in Darwin, marked this year's International Week of Deaf People.

They were hosted in Deaf spaces where Auslan is the first language, everyone feels safe, and inclusion is paramount.

The NT celebration also coincided with International Day of Sign Languages, a fitting occasion as Auslan is strongly tied to identity in the Deaf community.

Sofie shared her story with the ABC through Deaf Connect interpreter Bettina Girdler. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Sofie Waldron, 13, has been using sign language since infancy and said events such as these promoted a sense of belonging.

"Auslan is my first language, it's natural for us to use it, and English is my second language," she said.

While it can be nerve-wracking meeting new people, the teen said Deaf spaces make socialising feel more comfortable.

"I feel more calm and connected, just like I can engage more with people, sometimes it is difficult to understand people when they just speak English," she said.

Sofie is also part of her school's Deaf club, which offers space to relax and communicate with others in Auslan.

She said it was encouraging to see hearing students joining in and learning to sign.

Sofie Waldron lives with her hearing family, including her protective big brother, and is teaching her baby sister Auslan. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Undeterred by the barriers of being the only deaf child in a hearing family, Sofie has been teaching her baby sister some sign language.

The teen would love to see more Auslan in schools, which she believes would led to less miscommunication and isolation.

It's a belief shared by Ms Davis, who described the ability to sign as a birth right.

The Auslan teacher wants all deaf babies to "have access to their language from day dot, all throughout their life".

Unfortunately, that isn't always the case.

The social game of lawn bowls was one of 16 inclusive events hosted by Deaf Connect across the country this week. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Despite Darwin being home to many deaf children, some of them struggle without classroom interpreters.

Ms Davis said insufficient funding for interpreters was "a nationwide challenge", but isolated regions were hit particularly hard.

Accessibility has improved over time — the NT government announced in May it would commit $120,000 annually to help Deaf Connect continue providing interpreting services — but there's still a long way to go before achieving equality.

Learning sign language

Ms Davis said some students were anxious when starting their sign language journey, but all were met with plenty of encouragement in a low-pressure environment.

"We love it when people start learning Auslan," Ms Davis said.

The classes were a lifeline for Divya Prasad when she moved to Darwin from the Middle East three years ago.

The mother-of-two lost her hearing as a toddler and, while her own family doesn't use sign language, the local Deaf community became like a second family.

Loading...

Ms Prasad relied on lip-reading until learning Indian Sign Language at 17 years old, later picking up American Sign Language too.

She was happy to discover Deaf culture and Auslan after moving to Australia, which she said had strengthened her independence and sense of self.

Connecting with Ms Davis and feeling supported by the Deaf community "has been wonderful", she told the ABC.

Nichole Davis applauding in Auslan by shaking her open palms in the air. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

"I've realised that before my life here in Darwin there just wasn't awareness of Deaf community in my life, and now I feel like everything's improved," Ms Prasad said.

" We shouldn't be so isolated and face so many barriers, it would be great if we were all together as one community and able to communicate as equals. "

What is Deaf culture?

Deaf Connect said Australia's Deaf culture had been shaped by the rich history, language, and diverse experiences — including a number of intersectional communities, as well as hearing families and allies.

The World Federation of the Deaf introduced an international Deaf flag in 2023, celebrating the variety of sign languages practised globally.

The international flag was unveiled in July 2023. (Supplied: X/World Federation of the Deaf)

Deaf Connect said, even within Australia, unique Auslan dialects emerge.

For example the way some colours are signed differs between states, and Deaf First Nations communities have been using their own sign language dialects for centuries.

Sign names are another unique part of Deaf culture — akin to a special nickname, they're different for every individual and often tied to something personal.

Gregory Leeson lost his hearing later in life, picking up sign language from his wife Brenda who is also deaf.

His sign name is tied to the long beard he's known for.

Greg Leeson demonstrating his unique sign name. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Demonstrating his unique sign name, Mr Leeson's hand forms a symbol that resembles a 'G' in American Sign Language — linking to his birth name — then swoops down over his moustache.

Ms Davis encouraged the wider community to embrace Deaf culture with an open mind.

"Some people think 'Oh, deaf people can't do this or they can't do that'," she said.

title: Tailor fined for smoking outside Adelaide CBD business
text:
A well-known Adelaide tailor and clothing retailer has been fined for smoking outside his CBD business in contravention of council by-laws but has been spared convictions to allow him to travel overseas and "keep abreast with fashion" trends.

Joseph Uzumcu, 66, who has traded from his Gawler Place shop for 38 years, appeared in the Adelaide Magistrates Court to be sentenced after pleading guilty to six counts of breaching an Adelaide City Council by-law that bans smoking in and around Rundle Mall.

The court heard one count related to a complaint from a member of the public who had seen Mr Uzumcu smoking in Gawler Place, while the other five counts were detected by CCTV or observations by council staff.

Defence lawyer Jon Lister asked the court to spare Mr Uzumcu a conviction so he could continue to attend international fashion events, because a conviction may "unduly prejudice" the tailor's career.

Joseph Uzumcu smoking outside his shop in Gawler Place. (Facebook)

Fears for fashion week dreams

"He, in the past, has travelled frequently to Europe, mostly to Italy, and to Japan for the purpose of keeping abreast with fashion developments at catwalks and fashion shows of that kind," Mr Lister said.

"It has been a long-term wish for him to attend the fashion week in New York and to attend a shoe fair in Los Angeles.

" He's concerned, your honour, that convictions for this matter may result in him being prohibited entry to the United States. "

Mr Lister said while the application process did not currently preclude Mr Uzumcu from travelling to the United States, "recent uncertainty about the manner in which executive decisions are made in the United States, under the Trump regime, has made him anxious that there may be a preclusion of him travelling if he's convicted of these offences".

He told the court a fine would be an adequate punishment for the breaches and said Mr Uzumcu apologised to the court and the member of the public who made the complaint.

Joseph Uzumcu spoke to the media outside court and said he would not advise younger generations to smoke. (ABC News: Jordanna Schriever)

"He's resolved, your Honour, to be very careful not to breach this by-law again, he'll be walking up to North Terrace for any cigarette smoking," Mr Lister said.

A lawyer for the council told the court Mr Uzumcu ought to have known smoking was prohibited because he had been fined for five similar breaches in 2017.

"Given the defendant's antecedent history, he ought to have known that smoking in Gawler Place as he did was prohibited and his conduct, the subject of these counts, shows disregard for the law and he should be deterred from doing so in the future," the council's lawyer said.

Tailor spared conviction

He said the council sought convictions for each count.

But Magistrate Natalie Browne spared Mr Uzumcu any convictions, imposed a $600 fine and ordered he pay prosecution costs of $699.

At the conclusion of the hearing, Mr Uzumcu told the court he would seek medical advice to give up smoking.

Outside court, he further explained that he had been smoking for more than 40 years and it was "a very unconscious" habit and it was "very, very nice" that he was not convicted.

"I run a very stressful business, I come out of the shop, I have a problem, I just light up a cigar," he said.

"I am guilty as charged … I should give up, absolutely. I would not advise any of the young generation to smoke because it is very difficult to give up."

title: Sculpture by the Sea offered $200,000 lifeline after financial woes
text:
Sculpture by the Sea has been offered a $200,000 lifeline after organisers made an urgent plea for funding just weeks out from this year's event.

The annual exhibition, which is held on the Bondi to Tamarama cliff walk, was facing cancellation ahead of its October 17 start date after failing to secure federal government funding.

Founder David Handley said the event relied on a combination of funding from the state government and Waverely Council, but had not received any federal money for the last two years, resulting in a $200,000 shortfall.

After a public appeal for donations, organisers announced on Friday morning that it had acquired a major partnership with NRMA Insurance and the event will now go ahead as planned.

Mr Handley told ABC Radio Sydney the $200,000 would go towards paying this year's artists and safeguarding future operations.

"We're going to be able to take time to reflect on how we try to set up Sculpture from the Sea as a more sustainable operation with a future fund," he said.

Members of the public donated more than $125,000 within 30 hours of the appeal. (Supplied: Mitsuo Takeuchi)

In addition, the event also received more than $125,000 in public donations within the 30 hours of launching its appeal.

Mr Handley said the response had been "extraordinary".

"We went right down to the wire, that's why we had to do this desperate plea. We are not an organisation with cash reserves," he said.

The annual sculpture walk, which attracts around 450,000 visitors each year, typically costs around $3 million with installation alone coming to $800,000.

Founder David Handley, artists Kasane Low and Niharika Hukku, and 2023 Sculpture by the Sea winner John Petrie. (ABC News: Pablo Vinales)

Artists who exhibit at Sculpture by the Sea spend an average of $15,000 on each artwork, inclusive of materials, transportation and installation costs.

Mr Handley said artists are paid $3,000 and the remainder of the money goes towards holding the exhibition as a free-to-the public event.

"This year over $300,000 from our donors and sponsors is going directly into artists' pockets to help them with their costs," he said.

"We started this with volunteers working out of my lounge room with $100 in the bank."

Artists who exhibit at Sculpture by the Sea spend an average of $15,000 on each artwork. (Supplied: Yoshiho Futo)

Organisers had criticised Creative Australia — the government's peak arts body — for the shortfall in funding.

Creative Australia claimed the event had not submitted an application for funding, including from its recent arts project investments for organisations program.

"Funding does not automatically renew at the end of a funding cycle. To be considered for funding, organisations must apply for funding through an open and competitive process," a spokesperson said.

title: Former foster child tells inquiry he felt 'like cargo' in strained system
text:
It took Chance Kennedy 14 years to finally feel secure.

He first entered care as a toddler. He was in and out of foster and residential care.

There were spates of reunification with his mother, before her drug use forced him, as a child, to call Child Safety and ask to be taken back in.

Now in his 20s, the quietly spoken Mr Kennedy this week told a room full of lawyers in Cairns about his time in care, as part of the regional hearings of the Child Safety Commission of Inquiry.

In his ambition to "leave no stone unturned", Commissioner Paul Anastassiou KC has heard from foster carers, kin carers and as child safety workers running residential homes.

In the third and final week of sittings in Cairns, Mr Kennedy explained how at the age of 10 he was put in 15 to 20 different placements in as many days.

"Especially when you're only at houses for one or two days, and then you're just moved around, you start to feel a bit like cargo," he said.

He said the lack of stability continued to impact him and his sense of self-worth.

"When you're at 20 different houses in as many days, you start to feel like, 'OK, well, nobody wants me', so then you just shut off emotionally, because there's no point getting attached," he said.

For several years, Mr Kennedy lived in a home that some of the commission lawyers referred to as a "foster farm".

Sharing a room with four to five other children, he said they were given different food to the parents and forced to work for one of the carer's lawn care businesses without pay.

Paul Anastassiou KC sat for three weeks of hearings in Cairns. (AAP: Darren England)

"It was almost an expectation that you would help; otherwise, you know, you'd fear not getting fed," he said.

He said the father would drink while the children worked, and the adults would throw empty soft drink cans at them if they were annoyed.

"We were never treated as children … probably more of an annoyance," he said.

After several more placements lasting from a few weeks to two years, at 14, Mr Kennedy said he finally landed a spot with a foster carer who gave him the stability and care he craved.

It was the one thing he urged the commission to prioritise.

"If possible, don't just keep moving us around," he said.

Medical delays

Foster carers and Child Safety officers have described a fraught and strained system, made up of a "labyrinth" of meetings and bureaucracy and vulnerable children losing at every turn.

Multiple foster carers outlined the distress caused by lengthy delays in getting children access to medical care.

Managers of multiple residential care homes in the Far North gave evidence during the inquiry. (ABC Far North: Holly Richardson)

Foster carer Gayle McLaren told the inquiry she cared for a child who needed 14 fillings and five adult teeth removed.

Each child is allocated $1,100 every two years for dental care, and that had already been spent on previous dental work.

Ms McLaren said Child Safety told her she had to take the child to a public dentist, which meant a four to six-month waiting list for treatment.

"This child is needing Panadol, ibuprofen most days and nights because she's in pain," she said.

She also described attempting to get specialised treatment for a child with scabies. Eventually, she paid for the dermatologist herself.

A kinship carer, who could not be named for legal reasons, said he was still waiting, after more than 18 months, for a child in his care to see a paediatrician.

He said he would like to see children assessed as soon as possible when they entered the care system.

Access to timely medical care was an issue repeated by multiple foster and kin carers and former foster children. (ABC News: Curtis Rodda)

Anglicare North Queensland chief executive Liz Colahan told the commission that in her years working for various organisations in Child Safety, the number of different agencies and people involved had ballooned.

She said this had inadvertently created more cracks for children to fall through.

Residential care homes

The care children receive in residential care homes — where multiple children are housed in a building, with a team of staff rotating in — also came under scrutiny.

Retired manager at Child Safety Innisfail Ralph Laksa said residential care should feel like a child's home but acknowledged many did not meet that standard.

The commission held hearings around Cairns and is expected to hold further sessions in regional Queensland. (ABC News: Brendan Mounter)

"I've seen residentials where they've taken the cupboard doors off the kitchen, they're replaced all the crockery with plastic plates, removed photos for them being thrown around," he said.

" They're just concrete besser block homes with no love, no care, no emotion in the home. "

The Cairns hearings are expected to wrap up today with further hearings yet to be announced.

title: Former Arsenal player dies aged 21 after suffering brain injury during game
text:
Former Arsenal-contracted player Billy Vigar has died aged 21 after sustaining a "significant brain injury" while playing for Chichester City last weekend.

Vigar was injured in an Isthmian League match at Wingate and Finchley, leading to the game's abandonment after 13 minutes.

"After sustaining a significant brain injury last Saturday, Billy Vigar was put in an induced coma. On Tuesday, he needed an operation to aid any chances of recovery. Although this helped, the injury proved too much for him and he passed away on Thursday morning," a statement from the seventh-tier Chichester read.

"The responses to the original update show how much Billy was thought of and loved within the sport. His family are devastated that this has happened whilst he was playing the sport that he loved."

Vigar joined Arsenal's academy as a 14-year-old in 2017, before signing a professional contract in 2022. He was loaned to Derby and Eastbourne Borough before joining Hastings United in 2024. He linked up with Chichester at the start of this season.

"Everyone at Arsenal Football Club is deeply sorry to hear of the tragic passing of Chichester City forward and former Arsenal academy player, Billy Vigar," a statement from Arsenal read.

"Billy joined our academy on schoolboy terms aged 14, after being scouted at his home town club Hove Rivervale FC and excelled as a striker at Hale End, scoring 17 goals in his debut season.

"As well as his significant talent, Billy will always be remembered for his love of the game, pride at representing our football club — he once called the day he was spotted by our scouts as 'the most important of his life' — and a character beloved by teammates and coaches alike.

"Our deepest condolences go out to the Vigar family and his many friends at this extremely difficult time."

title: Live: CSL falls on Trump tariffs on pharmaceuticals from October while ASX edges lower
